descriptions: Arbitrary-length logical constant-depth CNOT ladder. A ⊕ on a measured data bit is flipped if the sum (modulo 2) of the measured ancilla bits above it with an ⊕ is 1. The qubits with/without a Hadamard applied at the start are ancilla/data qubits, respectively.

Arbitrary-length logical constant-depth CNOT ladder. A on a measured data bit is flipped if the sum (modulo 2) of the measured ancilla bits above it with an is 1. The qubits with/without a Hadamard applied at the start are ancilla/data qubits, respectively. As discussed in , an additional tool we have in our

Logical circuit for a 5 CNOT, constant-depth CNOT-ladder on a 4×2 grid of qubits. The brackets surround qubits on the same row. The dashed lines separate the circuit into three parts: the first creates a Bell pair between the ancilla row and the second data row, the second consists of the CNOTs from the first two sections of the original circuit (Figure <ref>) being executed in parallel, and the third consists of the final CNOT from the original circuit, measurement, and classical correction.

Logical Architecture Uniting Motion and In-Place Entanglement: Shor’s Algorithm, Constant-Depth CNOT Ladder, and Many-Hypercube Code Logical qubits are considered an essential component for achieving utility-scale quantum computation. Multiple recent demonstrations of logical qubits on neutral atoms have relied on coherent qubit motion into entangling zones. However, this architecture requires motion prior to every entangling gate, incurring significant cost in wall clock runtime and motion-related error accumulation. We propose and experimentally realize an alternative architecture which
L=2 Many-hypercube state preparation circuit. The five pairs of qubits are initialized to the logical |0 0⟩ L state of the [[4,2,2]] code (Equation <ref>).

L=2 [[4,2,2]] [[4,2,2]] X Z [[16,4,4]] L=2 [[4,2,2]] [[16,4,4]] L=2 d=4 X state of the [[4, 2, 2]] code (Equation ). We collected experimental results for unencoded and encoded ([[16, 4, 4]]) state preparation of the following bitstrings -- ``1110", ``0000", ``0111", and ``1111". The measurements of these circuits are post-processed via loss detection and decoding (for the encoded circuits). Stabilizer values are reconstructed from data qubit measurements at the end of the circuit. As a result, only stabilizers are used for decoding. Across all bitstrings, the encoded circuits have a lower

Example of how redundant CX pairs appear and how to remove them. (a) will decompose a multi-qubit controlled operator into RCCX gates (illustrated as CCX gates in the figure) and a single controlled-U gate. (b) can eliminate redundant control operations depending on the states of qubits. (c) Redundant CX pairs can be removed once they are identified as redundant.

example, when the state of two control qubits is a superposition of , , and , we can remove the control operation from the rightmost qubit, replacing the or gate with a gate. When the control operation is removed from the first gate of the pair produced in the decomposition (see Figure (a)), the second gate of the pair can be also replaced according to the optimization result of the first gate. The higher the noise threshold becomes, the stronger the reduction of the control operations, hence the less equivalent the optimized circuit to the original one. The reduction of noisy control

decomposition methods to decompose circuit into its elementary gates followed by applying a set of simplification rules to simplify and optimize the synthesized quantum circuit. The proposed algorithms achieve a reduction in the quantum cost of synthesized quantum circuits when compared with relevant work in the literature. The proposed algorithms synthesize quantum circuits that can applied on IBM quantum computer. theorem definition Definition Example Simplification Rule [1] #1 [1][htb] Strategy [#1] do while 10pt plus 2pt minus 2pt The construction of quantum computers is based on the synthesis of low-cost quantum circuits. The quantum circuit of any Boolean function expressed in a Positive Polarity Reed-Muller expansion can be synthesized using Multiple-Control Toffoli ( ) gates. This paper proposes two algorithms to construct a quantum circuit for any Boolean function expressed in a Positive Polarity Reed-Muller expansion. The Boolean function can be expressed with various algebraic forms, so there

Reversible circuit of f 1 where (a) represents f 1 in Eq.(<ref>), (b) represents f 1 after decomposing the first gate without remove any gate and (c) represents f 1 after decomposing the first gate and remove the last gate that has no effect on the result of f 1 where g is a garbage qubit with QC=4 2.

reversible and quantum circuits to minimize quantum cost. One of these methods constructs the reversible circuits with extra ancillary bits that will increase the hardware cost . A rule-based optimization algorithm uses multiple control Toffoli gates with both negative and positive controls which merges Toffoli gates with common target and introduces rules for optimizing reversible circuits and sub-circuits that have a common target. Another method uses a Quantum Operator Form to minimize the quantum cost that allows the usage of different quantum gates , and . In , the Multi Controls Target
